title: Development of high-speed fiber-optic communication lines for transferring large amounts of information
abstract: In this article, the mode composition of the microstructured optical fiber was calculated. The values of the effective (waveguide) refractive index of the first six spatial modes, the propagation of which are supported by an optical fiber, are calculated. The structures of microstructured fiber have been manufactured and presented. An experimental study of the distribution of optical radiation at the exit from the manufactured microstructured fiber has been carried out. The results of the research are presented.

abstract.text: In this article, the mode composition of the microstructured optical fiber was calculated. The values of the effective (waveguide) refractive index of the first six spatial modes, the propagation of which are supported by an optical fiber, are calculated. The structures of microstructured fiber have been manufactured and presented. An experimental study of the distribution of optical radiation at the exit from the manufactured microstructured fiber has been carried out. The results of the research are presented.

body_text.text: In the modern world, the volumes of transmitted information are constantly increasing [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] . This information must be transmitted over long distances in short periods of time [5] [6] [7] [8] . Every year the number of tasks increases when information is exchanged in an Permission to make digital or hard copies of all or part of this work for personal or classroom use is granted without fee provided that copies are not made or distributed for profit or commercial advantage and that copies bear this notice and the full citation on the first page. To copy otherwise, or republish, to post on servers or to redistribute to lists, requires prior specific permission and/or a fee. Request permissions from permissions@acm.org. ICFNDS 2021, December interactive mode with the participation of a large number of users [9] [10] [11] . To solve these problems, various communication systems are used [10] [11] [12] [13] [14] [15] [16] . Among terrestrial communication systems, fiber-optic communication lines (FOCL) have the greatest advantages [17] [18] [19] [20] . It should be noted that fiber-optic communication lines are also included in the systems of cellular and satellite communication lines, performing an important function in their composition [8, 14, 18, [21] [22] [23] . The main problem that is now being faced when transmitting large amounts of information over fiber-optic communication lines is the limit on the speed and volume of data transmitted over a single-mode fiber, both on trunk communication lines and on local ones [23] [24] [25] [26] . Technologies of wavelength division multiplexing of information in communication channels have reached their limit. An increase in the density in the fiber-optic communication line leads to the loss of information or a sharp increase in the signal attenuation during transmission [25] [26] [27] . The currently developed multimode fibers do not provide the transmission of the required amounts of information, especially over long distances. Therefore, various developments and research aimed at solving this problem are extremely relevant.

One of the possible solutions may be the use of a microstructured fiber with a given mode composition [25] [26] [27] [28] . The use of these fibers makes it possible to increase the amount of transmitted information due to its distribution between adjacent modes. These fibers, like single-mode ones, are resistant to temperature changes and mechanical stress. To transmit large amounts of information over long distances in a microstructured fiber, it is necessary to provide a certain topology of the channels, their size and pitch between them. These parameters are highly dependent on the fiber manufacturing technology (temperature, pressure, drawing speed and frequency of longitudinal twisting of the optical fiber around its axis, etc.). The optimal choice of these parameters makes it possible to ensure the presence in the fiber of only three modes (LP 01 , LP 11 , LP 21 ) necessary for the stable transmission of large amounts of information and low losses (minimal leakage of the optical signal). For each microstructured optical fiber topology, these parameters differ from each other, especially in the case of using different fiber technologies. Therefore, a comprehensive solution to this problem is presented in the work (experimental studies have

Before the manufacture of a microstructured optical fiber, in most cases, a numerical calculation of its mode characteristics is performed. For each equipment and technological cycle, it is necessary to carry out its own calculation. In our case, the calculation was performed in the COMSOL Multiphysics software for the following parameters of a fiber with a displaced core: the number of orders of circular cross-section holes -4; structure pitch (distance between adjacent holes) -10.9 microns; the outer diameter of the fiber is 125 microns; laser radiation wavelength λ = 1550 nm; the structure filling parameter (k), determined by the size of the voids in the order surrounding the cores, is 0.95. Based on the results of numerical modeling by the finite element method in the COMSOL Multiphysics software environment, the values of the effective (waveguide) refractive index of the first six spatial modes were obtained, the propagation of which is supported by an optical fiber (Figure 1 ).
body_text.section: CALCULATION OF THE MOD COMPOSITION OF A MICROSTRUCTURED OPTICAL FIBER

body_text.text: Analysis of the results obtained shows a small difference between the effective refractive index for the first four modes. This allows us to conclude that their distribution is stable. Further, the difference increases, which in practice will be characterized by excessive attenuation of the optical signal. Therefore, in fiber, it is most preferable to transmit information using the fundamental mode (LP 01 ) or the first three higher modes (LP 11 , LP 21 , and LP 02 ).
body_text.section: CALCULATION OF THE MOD COMPOSITION OF A MICROSTRUCTURED OPTICAL FIBER

body_text.text: When researching the operation of information transmission systems with microstructured optical fibers, one of the important parameters is the spatial distribution of laser radiation in the cross section of the fiber for various modes. Using the results of numerical simulation by the finite element method in the COMSOL Multiphysics software environment, the distribution of laser radiation was obtained for the first six spatial modes, the propagation of which is supported by an optical fiber. These results are shown in figure 2 The data obtained show the great possibilities of microstructured optical fibers for information transmission.
body_text.section: CALCULATION OF THE MOD COMPOSITION OF A MICROSTRUCTURED OPTICAL FIBER

body_text.text: The technology for manufacturing microstructured fibers with a given modal composition consists in choosing an internal structure that is assembled with the help of capillaries. Then they are inserted into a quartz tube for further drawing. In figure 3 shows an example of one of the blanks Fiberglass fibers with concentric birefringent or non-concentric cores are spun at high speed while passing through a miniature oven in a drawing machine. Depending on the location of the capillaries and the technological cycle, different topologies of chiral microstructured fibers can be obtained. In figure 4 shows one of them (a star).
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF OPTICAL RADIATION AT THE EXIT FROM A MICROSTRUCTURED FIBER

body_text.text: In figure 5 shows the distribution of optical radiation at the exit from the microstructured fiber (star topology) at different speeds of rotation of the preform per meter of fiber length.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF OPTICAL RADIATION AT THE EXIT FROM A MICROSTRUCTURED FIBER

body_text.text: The research results showed the dependence of the mode composition on the rotation speed of the workpiece. This makes it possible to optimize the technological process to obtain the required mode composition in the optical fiber for information transmission.
body_text.section: EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF OPTICAL RADIATION AT THE EXIT FROM A MICROSTRUCTURED FIBER

body_text.text: The results obtained show that the use of spatial modes LP 01 , LP 11 , LP 21 strongly affects the stability of the final signal due to the similar geometry of the intensity distribution. High signal stability allows The proposed technique for selecting the parameters of the technological process for the manufacture of microstructured fibers allows obtaining a clear resolution of three modes in the fiber for transmitting large amounts of information. It was found that the rotation rate affects the mode composition of the optical fiber by increasing the attenuation of individual modes. It can be assumed that for certain pressures and temperatures, the rotation speed is a mode filter.
